learningObject.name: High Voltage Distance Learning: Theoretical Concepts
learningObject.text:
Please note that this section is not compulsory and contains no assessment questions. The reason that this is not a compulsory section, is since many candidates are already experienced electrical engineers and will therefore be familiar with the theoretical concepts relating to High Voltage.We do however recommend you work through the session as a refresher; or of you have little or no electrical experience.

NOTE: It is not the aim of this section train a candidate to become an Electrical Engineer.

list.name: Physical Concepts
list.text: The links below discuss some of the important physical definitions that relate to electricity.

listItem.name: Charge
listItem.text:
The unit of charge is the coulomb (C) where one coulomb is one ampere second (1 coulomb = 6.24 × 1018 electrons) 
The coulomb is defined as the quantity of electricity which flows past a given point in an electrical circuit when a current of one ampere is maintained for one second.

The quantity of charge in coulombs:   Q = it

Where i is the current and t is the time in seconds

listItem.name: Force
listItem.text:
The unit of force is the newton (N) where one newton is one kilogram metre per second squared. The newton is defined as the force which, when applied to a mass of one kilogram, gives it an acceleration of one metre per second squared.

Force in newtons: F = ma

Where (m) is the mass in kilograms and (a) is the acceleration in metres per second squared

listItem.name: Work
listItem.text:
The unit of force is the newton (N) where one newton is one kilogram metre per second squared. The newton is defined as the force which, when applied to a mass of one kilogram, gives it an acceleration of one metre per second squared.

Force in newtons:  F = ma

Where (m) is the mass in kilograms and (a) is the acceleration in metres per second squared

Work done on a body in joules:  W = fs
Where (f) is the force in newtons and (s) is the distance in metres moved by the body in the direction of the force.  

Energy is the capacity for doing work!

listItem.name: Power
listItem.text:
The unit of power is the watt (w) where one watt is one joule per second.  Power is defined as the rate of doing work or transferring energy:

Power in Watts: \( \sf P=\frac{w}{t}\)

Where (w) is the work done or energy transferred, in joules, and (t) is the time, in seconds

nestedPage.name: Voltage
nestedPage.text:
The unit of electrical potential is the volt (V), where one volt is one joule per coulomb. One volt is defined as the difference in potential between two points in a conductor which, when carrying a current of one ampere, dissipates a power of one watt,

A change in electrical potential between two points in an electrical circuit is called a potential difference.  The electromotive force (EMF) provided by a source of energy such as a battery or a generator is measured in volts.

nestedPage.name: Current
nestedPage.text:
Within all material there are atoms and within those atoms electrons are present; some of these electrons are called 'free electrons' which can move freely and indefinitely between the atoms. However, if an electric pressure or voltage is applied across the material there is a tendency for these electrons to move in a particular direction. This constitutes electric current.

Conventional current is actually opposite to the flow of electrons and is always referred as the flow of current from a positive to a negative potential.

Current is annotated by 'I' the units of which are amperes or  amps, named after the French physicist Andre-Marie Ampere.

nestedPage.name: Resistance
nestedPage.text:
The unit of electrical resistance is the ohm (Ω), where one ohm is one volt per ampere.  It is defined as the resistance between two points in a conductor when a constant electrical potential of one volt applied at the two points produces a current flow of one ampere in the conductor:

Where V is the potential difference across the two points, in volts, and I is the current flowing between the two points in amperes. The reciprocal of resistance is called conductance and is measured in siemens (S)

\( \sf Conductance\:in\: siemens:\:G=\frac{1}{R}\)

Where (R) is the resistance in ohms

nestedPage.name: Capacitance
nestedPage.text: Capacitance is the ability of a component to store electrical charge.  A capacitor consists of two conductive plates separated by a dielectric material. (An electrical insulator that can be polarized by an applied electric field). Capacitance is measured in farads (usually microfarads) and is dependent on the size of plate, separation distance and type of dielectric.

nestedPage.name: Electrical Power
nestedPage.text:
Power (P) in an electrical circuit is given by the product of potential difference (V) and current (I); as previously stated the unit of power is the watt (W).

Therefore:

\( \sf P=V \times I\; Watts\)

\( \sf P = I^{2}R\; Watts\)

\( \sf P = \frac{V^{2}}{R}\; Watts\)

As you can see there, are three possible formulae for calculating power.

Power in an AC circuit will be discussed later in this section

nestedPage.name: Ohms Law
nestedPage.text:
Using the Ohm’s law triangle is a good visual reminder of the relationship between I, V, and R and also assists in the selection of the required equation.

Ohm’s law states that the current (I) flowing in a circuit is directly proportional to the applied voltage (V) and inversely proportional to the resistance (R), provided the temperature remains constant.

The following equations may be used:

\( \sf I=\frac{V}{R}\)

\( \sf V = IR\)

\( \sf R=\frac{V}{I}\)

nestedPage.name: Series Resistor Network
nestedPage.text:
Resistors in an electrical circuit can either be in series or parallel. This diagram illustrates two resistors in series; R1 has a value of 4Ω and R2 has a value of 10Ω.

The total resistance (Rt) is calculated as follows:

Rt = R1 + R2
Rt = 4 + 10
Rt = 14Ω

nestedPage.name: Parallel Resistor Network
nestedPage.text:
This diagram shows resistors in parallel. The total resistance here is calculated as follows:

\( \sf \frac{1}{Rt}=\frac{1}{R1} + \frac{1}{R2}\)

\( \sf \frac{1}{Rt}=\frac{1}{4} + \frac{1}{10}\)

\( \sf \frac{1}{Rt}=\frac{7}{20} \)

Rt = 2.8Ω (Approximately)

nestedPage.name: Electrical Power
nestedPage.text:
Power (P) in an electrical circuit is given by the product of potential difference (V) and current (I); as previously stated the unit of power is the watt (W).

Therefore:

\( \sf P=V \times I\; Watts\)

\( \sf P = I^{2}R\; Watts\)

\( \sf P = \frac{V^{2}}{R}\; Watts\)

As you can see there, are three possible formulae for calculating power.

list.name: Kirchoff's Laws
list.text: This section introduces some basic Electrical Calculations that include:

listItem.name: Kirchoff's Voltage Law: Series Circuits
listItem.text: In a series circuit, the total voltage supplied by the source must equal the total voltage used by all of the loads in that path.

listItem.name: Kirchoff's Voltage Law: Parallel Circuits
listItem.text:
In a parallel circuit, the total voltage supplied by the source is equal to the voltage across each parallel branch

Note: This assumes all the loads are identical, ie have the same resistance.

listItem.name: Kirchoff's Current Law: Series Circuits
listItem.text: In a series circuit, the total current flowing through the circuit is identical at any point in the circuit.

listItem.name: Kirchoff's Current Law: Parallel Circuits
listItem.text: In a parallel circuit, the total current flowing through the circuit is divided up among any parallel branches.

list.name: Induction
list.text:
This short section introduces the concept of Induction.

Induction is the process whereby a voltage is produced when a electrical conductor is placed in a changing magnetic field.

listItem.name: Induction: Changing Magnetic Field
listItem.text:
When the magnet is moved at a constant speed towards the coil, as in the diagram, a deflection is noted on the ammeter showing that a current has been produced in the coil.

When the magnet is moved away, in the opposite direction, at the same speed, the same deflection is noted but in the opposite direction.

When the magnet is held stationary, even within the coil, no deflection is recorded.

If the coil is moved at the same speed and the magnet held stationary, the same ammeter deflection is noted in both directions.

It is the relative movement of the magnetic flux and the coil that causes an EMF and thus a current, to be induced in the coil.  This effect is known as electromagnetic induction.

listItem.name: Induction: Moving a coil within a magneitc field
listItem.text:
Conversely, if a conductor within an electrical circuit is moved through a magnetic field then a current is induced into the conductor.

In this example the coil is being rotated in a magnetic field.  This is a basic example of a current generator.

listItem.name: Induction: Examples of Components
listItem.text: Components within an ROV system that utilise the effects of induction include:

tabNav.name: Capacitance & Inductance
tabNav.text:
Capacitance is the ability of a component to store electrical charge at a given voltage.

Inductance is a little more complex to understand. In its simplest form Inductance can be thought of as the tendency of an electrical conductor to oppose the change in electric current. The change refers to that which takes place when an alternating current passes through the conductor and varies between a positive level and negative level. Alternating Current is discussed later in this section.

nestedPage.name: A Basic Capacitor
nestedPage.text: Capacitance is the ability of a component to store electrical charge.  A capacitor consists of two conductive plates separated by a dielectric material. (An electrical insulator that can be polarized by an applied electric field). Capacitance is measured in farads (usually microfarads) and is dependent on the size of plate, separation distance and type of dielectric.

nestedPage.name: Capacitive Circuits
nestedPage.text:
The capacitive circuit shown consists of a Resistor (R) and Capacitor (C). When the switch (S) closes the voltage across the Capacitor is zero and maximum current will flow through the capacitor. However as the Capacitor charges the current begins to decay. After a period of time the Cpacitor is fully charged and the current decays to zero. This time is equivalent to five 'time constants'. One time constant is calculated as follows:

T = C × R

Where (C) = Capacitance and (R) = Resistance

Components called capacitors store electrical energy and have many uses in electrical and electronic circuits.

For example, smoothing rectified AC outputs, radio receivers, MRI body scanners.

nestedPage.name: Series & Parallel Capacitance
nestedPage.text:
As with resistor networks, capacitors can be connected both in series or parallel. The illustration shows capacitors in series and parallel.

The total capacitance is calculated as follows:

In series:

\( \sf \frac{1}{Ct} = \frac{1}{C1} + \frac{1}{C2} + \frac{1}{C3}\)

In parallel:

\( \sf Ct = C1 + C2 + C3\)

nestedPage.name: Principle of Inductance
nestedPage.text:
When a current starts to flow in a coil a magnetic field will start to build up. However, as the field grows it will in-turn induce a secondary voltage into the coil which will oppose the original voltage. This is known as a “back EMF ” (electromotive force). This secondary voltage opposes the initial current flow. For this reason, the current flowing through the coil does not reach a maximum instantaneously.

This is also referred to as self-inductance

The property of the coil to resist the change in current is called inductance and is measured in Henries (H). One Henry is defined as the inductance of a circuit which produces a back EMF of 1 volt when the current is changing at 1A per second.

nestedPage.name: Inductance Curve
nestedPage.text:
The curve shown in the illustration is ‘exponential’; the current reaches a maximum after 5 time constants (5t).One time constant is equivalent to the Inductance divided by the resistance (L÷R). 

This idea can be applied to a solenoid. For example, if the coil has a resistance 30Ω and an inductance 0.1H then the time taken for the current to reach a maximum can be found as follows:

\( \sf Time\; Constant = \frac{L}{R} = 3.3ms\)

As the current reaches a maximum after five time constants it will reach a peak value at:

5 × 3.3ms = 16.5ms

Components called inductors are used when the property of inductance is required in an electrical circuit.

The basic form of an inductor is simply a coil of wire which can be used to reduce the effects of inductance in a circuit.

list.name: Alternating Current
list.text: This section introduces the basic concept of Alternating Current and how it is produced.

listItem.name: Simple Representation of Alternating Current
listItem.text:
Alternating Current can be represented in graphical form by what is known as a Sine Wave.

The voltage & current ‘alternate’ between a positive and negative value over a fixed period of time. The value is referred to as a ‘Peak to Peak’ (Vpp) and represents a peak voltage/current level.

In practice the actual voltage/current level is an average of the Peak to Peak Level. The common formula is 0.707 × the Peak to Peak level. This is referred to as RMS (Root Mean Squared) level and represents the actual voltage or current level.

The graph illustrates one complete cycle of the voltage/current waveform. The number of cycles that occur every second is called the ‘Frequency’ the units of which are Hertz (Hz). A typical mains voltage has a frequency of 50Hz.

The horizontal access of the graph represents what is called ‘Angular Velocity’ and is measured in degrees. The concept of Angular Velocity is complex and beyond the level of this course. In its basic form it represents the conductor that rotates in a magnetic field during the generation of Alternating Current. The following slides discuss this further.

listItem.name: AC Voltage & Current
listItem.text: It can be seen that the peak to peak level of the voltage is greater than that of the current. This is typical of an ROV power distribution system where voltage is kept high; and current low.

listItem.name: AC Generation
listItem.text:
We have already mentioned the principles of electromagnetic induction. If a copper conductor is passed through a magnetic field, a current will be induced into it.

If we now take a coil of wire wound onto a rectangular former and rotate this in a magnetic field we will induce an 'Electro Motive Force' (emf) into this wire. This, in turn, prodcuces a level of induced current, the level of which depends on how much magnetic flux is actually cut by the conductor.

The illustration shows one coil; in practice, there are many thousands of windings on the former.

In practice, the current output is via devices known as 'carbon brushes'. The carbon brush transfers the current from the rotating coil to stationary conductors that form, the output of the generator.

listItem.name: AC Generation (contd)
listItem.text:
The amount of EMF induced into a coil cutting the magnetic lines of force is determined by the following three factors:

  • Speed - the speed at which the coil rotates inside the magnetic field.
  • Strength - the strength of the magnetic field.
  • Length - the length of the coil or conductor passing through the magnetic field.

This diagram also illustrates the graphical representaion of AC current and Angular Velocity. It can be seen that peak level of current occurs at 90° and 270° respectively. One peak is positive and the other negative.

list.name: Reactance
list.text:
This section introduces 'Reactance'.

Reactance can be defined as the 'opposition to a change in current'. It has a similar notion to that of Resistance however is only noticeable in AC circuits whereas Resistance applies in DC circuits.

A components Reactance is due to the inductance or capacitance of the component.

listItem.name: Inductive Reactance
listItem.text:
In a DC circuit inductance creates a delay between the time of switch-on to the point when the current has risen to its maximum value. In an AC circuit however, the voltage is constantly changing, this results in a constant delay between the applied voltage and the resultant current.

The voltage leads current by 90°.

This however, assumes that the coil is of pure inductance and has no resistance. In reality any piece of wire will have some resistance, and the voltage will therefore lead the current somewhere between 0° and 90° this is known as the phase angle.

So we can see that inductance causes a delay but where that voltage is changing rapidly the current would not have enough time to reach its maximum.

The inductance now behaves like a resistance, limiting the current in the circuit, this is known as Inductive Reactance (XL) and is measured in ohms.

listItem.name: Capacitive Reactance
listItem.text:
As previously discussed, when passing a DC signal across a capacitor, current will only flow when the voltage is changing. This is between the point of switch-on and the point at which the voltage has risen to a maximum. Current is at a maximum when the rate of change of applied voltage is at its maximum. The rate of change of applied voltage is at its greatest when passing through zero and hence current flow is at a maximum.

When the voltage has risen to a maximum, the rate of change is now at a minimum and therefore the current flow will be at a minimum. If we continue to apply this logic throughout the cycle then the resulting current will be as shown.

The voltage lags current by 90°.

The fact that a capacitor will block a DC voltage but pass an AC signal is an important characteristic that is used throughout the field of electronics. It can now be seen that the faster voltage changes across a capacitor, the greater the current.

It could be said therefore that the opposition to current flow decreases as the frequency of the applied voltage increase.

The opposition to current flow is called capacitive reactance (Xc) and is measured in ohms.

tabNav.name: Impedance
tabNav.text: Impedance is the overall opposition to AC current flow in a circuit. Remember that a circuit will not only have pure resistance but also inductive or capacitive reactance. To determine impedance it is necessary to take all of these quantities into account.

nestedPage.name: Vector Diagram
nestedPage.text:
Due to the fact that inductive and capacitive reactances introduce different phase angles, it is necessary to use a vector diagram as illustrated to determine the impedance. This allows us to calculate impedance geometrically.

As resistance introduces no phase difference, the phasor line is drawn horizontally. The inductive and capacitive reactances are at 90º to the resistive properties and are therefore drawn at right angles as shown.

nestedPage.name: Calculating Impedence
nestedPage.text:
In this example the Inductive reactance XL is greater than the capacitive reactance XC. Each are 90° out of phase with the resistance.

  • The difference between the reactance's is therefore factored in to the calculation (XL - XC)
  • The Impedance (Z) is the resultant of the reactance's (XL - XC) and the Resistance (R)
  • The current due to the circuit impedance therefore lags the Resistance by an angle Ɵ

nestedPage.name: Calculating Impedance using Pythagoras
nestedPage.text:
In this example we build on the principle and introduce a mathematical equation to calculate the impedance. The equation is Pythagoras.

Pythagoras states that: H² = o² + a²

Where:

  • H = Hypotenuse (the side opposite the 90° angle
  • o = the side ‘Opposite’ the angle Ɵ
  • a = the side ‘adjacent’ to the angle

In this example the sides are representing the electrical properties.

  • Impedance Z
  • Resultant between Inductive and Capacitive Reactance's (XL - XC)
  • Resistance (R)

H² = o² + a²

Can now be substituted by…..

\( \sf Z^{2} = \left ( XL - XC \right )^{2} + R^{2}\)

\( \sf Z = \sqrt{\left ( XL - XC \right )^{2} + R^{2}}\)

The Phase Angle (Ɵ) can be calculated using the equation: 

\( \sf Cosine(\Theta ) = \frac{adjacent}{hypotenuse}\)

Or in this case

\( \sf Cosine(\Theta ) = \frac{R}{Z}\)

This angle is often referred to as the ‘Power Factor’.

tabNav.name: Power in an AC Circuit
tabNav.text:
The power consumed in a DC Circuit is simply the product of the Current and the Voltage (P=I × V) and the unit is Watts. The DC circuit is unaffected by the reactive components and the current and Voltage are therefore in phase.

In an AC circuit we have to consider the Inductive and Capacitive Reactive components and therefore calculate the power differently. We take into a number called the Power Factor which is derived from phase angle between the Voltage and Current.

nestedPage.name: The Power Factor
nestedPage.text:
In an AC circuit there will be capacitive and inductive properties within the components; the peak current and voltage levels will therefore be out of phase with each other as shown. This will mean that power cannot be calculated n the same manner as in a DC circuit.

It is now necessary to take into account a quantity known as the 'power factor'. The Power Factor is a value, between 0 and 1, and is actually the cosine of the phase angle we introduced in the section on Reactance.

\( \sf Power\; factor = Cos\, \theta = \frac{R}{Z}\)

nestedPage.name: Power in VA and kVA
nestedPage.text:
In a theoretical, purely resistive circuit where voltage and current are in phase then ᴓ = 0 and therefore:

Cos ᴓ = 1, (the cosine of 0 being 1); in this instance power in watts is:

Power = I (RMS) × V (RMS) × I

To quote the output power of an AC device in watts is not very practical.  This is because in order to have any idea of the value of current we would have to know the power factor of the device.

For this reason power ratings are often quoted in Volt Amps (VA) or Kilo Volt Amps (kVA)

Power (VA) = I (RMS) × V (RMS)

The power rating in VA does not represent the useful power that will be dissipated by the device. 

As we know, this is measured in watts, and is only dissipated by the resistive property in the circuit. 

It follows therefore that the closer we can reduce the angle ᴓ to zero, i.e. reduce the inductive reactance, and thus bring the power factor closer to unity; the more real power is available.

nestedPage.name: Beer Glass Analogy
nestedPage.text:
The beer glass analogy is a useful way of understanding Power in an AC Circuit.

  • The actual beer represents the useful power that does the work
  • The froth represents the wasted power
  • The full pint represents the power being demanded by the system.

It follows that we try and keep the froth to a minimum and the beer to a maximum!!!

learningObject.text:
A transformer is an electrical device which, by the principles of electromagnetic induction (as previously discussed), transfers electrical energy from one electric circuit to another, without changing the frequency. The energy transfer usually takes place with a change of voltage and current.

Transformers either increase or decrease AC voltage.

The illustration represents the essential elements for a transformer - a magnetic core, with a primary and secondary coil wound on the limbs of the magnetic core.

Theory of operation

As an Alternating Current is passed through the primary coil an electromagnetic field is created as the current continually changes. The field builds and collapses at the same frequency as the primary current. As it does so it 'cuts' through the secondary winding and induces an 'Electro Magnetic Force' (EMF) into the secondary coil. A current now flows through this coil and a voltage is therefore developed across any load that should be connected in the secondary circuit.

tabNav.name: Transformer Components
tabNav.text:
There are four primary parts to the basic transformer that are discussed here. They include:

  • Input Connections
  • Output Connections 
  • Windings/Coils
  • Core

nestedPage.name: Input Connection
nestedPage.text: The input side of a transformer is called the primary side because the main electrical power to be changed is connected at this point.

nestedPage.name: Output Connection
nestedPage.text: The output side or secondary side of the transformer is where the electrical power is sent to the load. Depending on the requirement of the load, the incoming electric power is either increased or decreased.

nestedPage.name: Windings/Coils
nestedPage.text: Transformers have two windings, the primary winding and the secondary winding. The primary winding is the coil that draws power from the source. The secondary winding is the coil that delivers the energy at the transformed or changed voltage to the load. Usually, these two coils are subdivided into several coils in order to reduce the creation of flux.

nestedPage.name: Core
nestedPage.text: The transformer core is used to provide a controlled path for the magnetic flux generated in the transformer. The core is generally not a solid bar of steel, rather a construction of many thin laminated steel sheets or layers. This construction is used to help eliminate and reduce heating.

tabNav.name: Types of Transformer
tabNav.text:
There are a range of differnt types of Transformer for different applications. The following are discussed here:

  • Shell & Core type Transformers
  • Step-Up Transformer
  • Step- Down Transformer
  • Multiple Output Transformer

nestedPage.name: Shell & Core Transformers
nestedPage.text:
Transformers generally have one of two types of cores; core type and shell type.

These two types are distinguished from each other by the manner in which the primary and secondary coils are placed around the steel core.

  • Core type - with this type, the windings surround the laminated core.
  • Shell type - with this type, the windings are surrounded by the laminated core.

nestedPage.name: Step-Up Transformers
nestedPage.text:
The ratio between the number of actual turns of wire in each coil is the key in determining the type of transformer and what the output voltage will be. The ratio between output voltage and input voltage is the same as the ratio of the number of turns between the two windings.

A transformer's output voltage is greater than the input voltage if the secondary winding has more turns of wire than the primary winding.

The output voltage is therefore stepped up, and considered to be a "step-up transformer".

nestedPage.name: Step-Down Transformers
nestedPage.text: If the secondary winding has fewer turns than the primary winding, the output voltage is lower. This is a "step-down transformer".

nestedPage.name: Multiple Output Transformers
nestedPage.text:
If the secondary winding has fewer turns than the primary winding, the output voltage is lower. Transformers may have multiple outputs or ‘tappings’ where different output voltages are available.

A typical ROV step-up transformer will have several outputs allowing a range of voltages to be selected. Higher voltages are selected for longer umbilicals to compensate for the voltage drop over the power conductors.

tabNav.name: Transformers on an ROV System
tabNav.text:
A Workclass ROV system typically has the following Transformers:

  • Three-Phase
  • Isolating Transformers
  • Current Transformers

nestedPage.name: Three Phase Transformers
nestedPage.text:
When a considerable amount of power is involved in the transformation of three-phase power, it is more economical to use a three-phase transformer.

The unique arrangement of the windings and core saves a lot of iron and is ideal for ROV system hydraulic power units.

Three-phase transformers have six windings; three primary and three secondary.

nestedPage.name: Isolating Transformers
nestedPage.text:
Technically, any true transformer, whether used to transfer signals or power, is isolating, as the primary and secondary are not connected by conductors but only by induction. However, only transformers whose primary purpose is to isolate circuits (as opposed to the more common transformer function of voltage conversion) are routinely described as isolation transformers.

An isolating transformer provides an additional safety precaution in circuits that are required to be isolated from earth, thus preventing typical earth faults occurring.

Many ROV systems have isolated supplies as the equipment is often required to work on steel decks in wet or damp environments. Such environments pose a serious hazard to engineers when engaged in maintenance activities.

nestedPage.name: Current Transformers
nestedPage.text:
Current transformers are used in ROV instrumentation to measure the current in HV supplies.

The current transformer is effectively a toroidal coil through which a current carrying conductor passes. The conductor forms the primary winding and the surrounding coil forms the secondary. The electro magnetic field in the primary interacts with the secondary winding and induces a smaller secondary current that is used for monitoring purposes.

nestedPage.name: Current Meter
nestedPage.text: Current Meters make use of Current Transformers that are located in ROV Power Distribution Units.

tabNav.name: Power Supplies
tabNav.text: Enter text for the page here

nestedPage.name: What is a Power Supply?
nestedPage.text: A power supply is a device that reduces mains voltage to a suitable level as required by other components in a system. A power supply in its simplest form may simply consist of a step-down transformer that will reduce the level of AC power. It is however more usual to think of a power supply as a device that converts main AC voltage to a stable DC voltage required by other components.

nestedPage.name: Components
nestedPage.text:
The main components in a power supply unit are:

  • Transformer
  • Rectifier
  • Smoothing capacitor/filter
  • Regulator/stabiliser

nestedPage.name: Transformer
nestedPage.text: The first stage of this process is transformation, and as previously discussed a step-down transformer would be the device used to reduce the incoming voltage to the required level.

nestedPage.name: Rectifier
nestedPage.text:
The second stage in this process takes the AC voltage and converts it into a DC voltage. This is known as rectification.

The circuit consists of a diode on the output side of the transformer. A diode is rather like an electrical version of a hydraulic check valve in that it only allows the signal to pass in one direction.

When the AC voltage rises to a certain level (approximately 0.6v with respect to 0 volts) on the first half of the cycle then the diode begins to conduct and the signal passes through. However, on the second half of the cycle the signal falls to a negative value and the diode cuts off. It can be seen from the illustration that this circuit acts as a half wave rectifier.

It can be seen that half wave rectification is not very efficient as it only uses half the cycle and does not provide a very smooth output.

It is better therefore to use the arrangement shown in the illustration which is known as full wave rectification.

Four diodes are now used, arranged in a bridge formation.

This is sometimes known as a bridge rectifier:

  • When point 1 on the transformer rises to a positive value, current flows across the load from right to left via diodes A and B.
  • When point 2 on the transformer output is positive, current flows in the same direction but this time via diodes C and D.

The output of this rectifier now consists of positive half cycles.

nestedPage.name: Smoothing
nestedPage.text:
• Smoothing is normally carried out by a large electrolytic capacitor.
  • The capacitor charges up rapidly to the level of the positive half cycle. Its discharge rate through the load is very slow; this means that it has hardly discharged at all before the next positive half cycle comes along.
  • When this happens the capacitor re-charges to a peak value. It can be seen in the illustration that the output is in the form of a ripple DC voltage.

nestedPage.name: Stabilisation
nestedPage.text:
Due to internal resistance of the in-built components it is likely that the load will draw a current from the power supply, resulting in a drop in voltage. It is also possible that the mains voltage could fluctuate. For this reason the power supply must have some form of stabilisation.

Stabilisation is usually carried out by a dedicated integrated circuit (IC). A component that can be used for this purpose, however, is a Zener diode, the symbol for which is illustrated to the right.

Stabilisation Curve

A Zener diode behaves in much the same way as a conventional diode; however, it will only block voltage in the reverse direction up to a certain level, after which it will start to conduct.

The diagram illustrates the characteristics of a Zener diode. It can be seen that it conducts current in the forward direction when the positive voltage is only minimal, as does an ordinary diode, and will only conduct from a negative voltage at a set level.

The diode is in effect ‘clamping’ the voltage and preventing it from falling below a predetermined level.

It is also possible to have two Zener diodes back-to-back as shown. In this instance the top diode will clip the voltage and prevent it from rising above a predetermined level.

list.name: Three Phase Power
list.text:
It is normal for workclass ROV systems to use a three-phase supply from a rig or vessel. This supply is normally stepped up using a transformer to a suitable voltage to power the ROV.

This section discusses the following:

  • 3-Phase Generation
  • 3 Phase Configurations including Star & Delta
  • 3-Phase Components including Soft Start Systems

tabNav.name: What is 3 Phase
tabNav.text:
Three-phase electrical power is used almost exclusively for the transmission of electrical power throughout the world. The concept was originally conceived by Nikola Tesla and was proven to be typically 150% more efficient than single-phase in the same power range.

In a single-phase unit, the power falls to zero three times during each cycle; in three-phase it never drops to zero and the power delivered to the load is the same at any instant. Also, in three-phase the conductors need only be 75% the size of conductors for single-phase for the same power output. This has obvious benefits for transmitting power over long line lengths.

nestedPage.name: How 3-Phase is generated
nestedPage.text:
As previously discussed, AC current is generated by rotating a coil of wire on a former in a magnetic field. If we now use three separate coils set at 120° to each other, then three individual sinusoidal voltages will be produced. Each Voltage will be out of phase with each other by 120° as shown in the illustration.

The output in this situation is called three-phase.

nestedPage.name: Labelling 3 Phase
nestedPage.text:
Phase rotation and correct identification of phases is very important when setting up HV power systems.

The implications of incorrect phase configuration can be quite serious. The most common symptom is the incorrect rotation of electric motors, which can include hydraulic power unit motors and electric thruster motors.

It is important to identify and connect phases in the correct manner when installing a system. The phases are normally colour-coded, numbered or both. The image here illsutrates the UK colour coding Pre and Post 2006 and that adopted in the US.

nestedPage.name: Advantages of 3-Phase
nestedPage.text:
3- Phase Configuration Offers the following advantages:

  • Three phases means there will be more current available to the system
  • This means the HPU motor will have a higher and smoother running torque
  • Three-phase motors are smaller than single-phase motors
  • Three-phase power is typically 150% more efficient than single-phase in the same power range
  • Conductors need only be 75% the size of conductors for single-phase for the same power output

tabNav.name: 3-Phase Configurations
tabNav.text:
Three Phase can be configured in what is referred to as either STAR or DELTA

A brief introduction to this is given here.

nestedPage.name: Star Configuration
nestedPage.text:
A three-phase generator can be configured in such a way that one end of all of the windings are electrically connected to each other.

This arrangement is commonly known as a Star configuration.

nestedPage.name: Star Configuration with Load
nestedPage.text:
In this example a load has been shown, on the right-hand side, this could typically represent the three-phase motor in the hydraulic power unit (HPU).

The windings on the left-hand side would represent the secondary of the step-up transformer at the surface end.

There is no neutral conductor on an ROV. This is because the ‘load’ (three phase motor) is considered to be a ‘balanced load’ where each winding draws the same amount of current.

A domestic supply however differs in the fact that the load consists of individual consumers (eg houses) that use varying amounts of current. The Neutral line is a requirement in what is then referred to as an ‘Unbalanced load’ that requires a return path. The return path is referred to as the 'Neutral' line.

nestedPage.name: Delta Configuration
nestedPage.text:
A three-phase supply can also be configured in a Delta arrangement, as shown in the illustration.

In this case the phase voltage and line voltage are equal. Delta configurations will also provide more current than an equivalent Star configuration.

tabNav.name: Three Phase Components
tabNav.text:
There are many 3-phase components that are found in power transmission systems. They include:

  • Transformers
  • Generators
  • Electric Motors
  • Distribution Systems

This section will however focus on the 'Soft Start' system that is used in many workclass ROV's and Launch Systems.

A Soft Start temporarily limits the voltage during the initial start up of heavy duty electric motors. If they were not present then the initial application of maximum supply Voltage, would give rise to extremely high start up currents. Such currents could lead to excessive heat and the 'burn out' of motors.

nestedPage.name: Star-Delta Soft Start
nestedPage.text:
AC power systems can be either configured in Star (Y) or Delta (Δ) configuration.

The key differences between Star and Delta are:

  • Delta provides lower voltage but more current
  • Star provides a higher voltage but less current

Utilising both Star and Delta in an AC power system, usually referred to as a 'soft start system', can be very useful.

For example, a motor on start-up can draw up to eight times its normal operating current. This can cause mechanical stress on the motor and shaft, as well as the electrodynamic stresses on the attached power cables and electrical distribution network. Using a soft start system can extend the lifespan of the system.

nestedPage.name: Electronic Soft Start
nestedPage.text:
Alternatively, the soft start system can be achieved electronically, providing the same soft start result.

The graph shown here illustrates the method of operation.

It can be seen that without the application of a Soft Start the current at 'start-up' can rise to 1000% of the normal running current. This could lead to severe damage of components such as electric monitors.

The Soft Start limits the main voltage by only allowing a percentage (typically 40%) of the cycle to pass to the load. As the motor gains speed the soft start gradually allows the voltage to rise to maximum supply voltage. The graph illustrates the effect this has on the current. It can be seen that although the current ( coloured green) exceeds normal optimum level, it does so in a controlled manner over a period of time (t). This limits the damaging effect that would otherwise be incurred if the current 'spiked' during start- up.
